I agree with this suggestion from John and it would simplify a lot the solution, removing the need of a filesystem flag. Also, I'd recommend using a timeout constant in seconds (or minutes) since it would remove the need of a counter; we can use the "created_at" field from the "loads" table, so that the solution would be like (high-level):

    audit_load = self.dbapi.load_get_by_state(constants.IMPORTING_LOAD_STATE)
    if datetime.utcnow() > audit_load["created_at"] + <timeout_constant_in_secs>:
        log an error message
        set load state to "error"
    else:
        log an info message

(timestamp arithmetic above probably need some conversion)

deployment/octavia/octavia-deployment-co.message:
in my opinion, the RAM should be (1024 * vcpus)
but maybe I'm wrong

Yeag, that is a good point. I did some research and found [1], which says that HAProxy can handle:

"about 5000 concurrent end-to-end TLS connections (both sides) per GB of
 RAM including the memory required for system buffers"
 
I would assume that with an amp with 4 vCPUs one would aim for 20k concurrent connections at least, so setting 4 GB of RAM here seem sensible to me. It's only a default after all.

[1]: https://www.haproxy.com/documentation/hapee/1-8r1/onepage/intro/#3.5

This commit log should be much more specific and deliberate. It reads like the problem isn't well understood, nor the actual solution selected being trustworthy. It should be much more specific and "confident". I believe what you are trying to say is...

---
At times running 'docker build' with stx-aptly.Dockerfile we see the curl command fail with the error "<insert error text here>". It has been determined that this is caused by a faulty version of the Debian package for 'ca-certificates'. While waiting for this package to be updated in Debian Bullseye we are enabling insecure mode for the curl command. This does carry risk in that the download may be susceptible to a man-in-the-middle attack so this workaround should be removed once an corrected 'ca-certificates' package is readily available.
---

Reviewers are expecting this level of detail in order to properly evaluate the change. Outline the issue, including the actual error text, outline the choice of fix as well as any side effects the change might have. You are already doing this work in devising the change, so share it with the reviewers to save them having to do their own research.

Setting this to -W while I look into the encryption_options.

droping +2 we talked about this a little offline.

we have 4 options

1 parse and convert the cryptesetup  format value for the lvm config option.
2 add new config options for the new feature
3 hard code a sane default and revisit this next cycle (this is my vote)
4 expose these via flavor extra specs/image propertiees in this cycle

4 is possibel the best long term solution but i am suggesting 3

because all of the other options technially need schduler support
which idealy would be traits based to make move ops work

if we only support one option for the encyption parmaters (the current default used by qemu) then we know it works on all hosts and we cna defer makign a choice about the way we express the encyption requirement and how to handel the schduler impact to next cycle.

> droping +2 we talked about this a little offline.
> 
> we have 4 options
> 
> 1 parse and convert the cryptesetup  format value for the lvm config option.
> 2 add new config options for the new feature
> 3 hard code a sane default and revisit this next cycle (this is my vote)
> 4 expose these via flavor extra specs/image propertiees in this cycle

With regard to option 4, from what I can tell in the spec + code, it was not intended for the encryption_options to be chosen by the end user via extra_specs/image_properties. The only configurability I see is by the operator/deployer only in nova.conf.

That said, we could obviously consider providing the options to end users but I just wanted to mention I don't think that was the original design.

> 4 is possibel the best long term solution but i am suggesting 3
> 
> because all of the other options technially need schduler support
> which idealy would be traits based to make move ops work
> 
> if we only support one option for the encyption parmaters (the current default used by qemu) then we know it works on all hosts and we cna defer makign a choice about the way we express the encyption requirement and how to handel the schduler impact to next cycle.

I am fine with option 3. The existing LVM config default is "aes-xts-plain64" and the defaults in qemu-img are cipher-alg = aes256, cipher-mode = xts, ivgen-alg = plain64. These are consistent between LVM and QEMU, reinforcing the idea that they would be good defaults to hard code as a start.

FWIW this is what I ended up with locally for parsing the existing LVM config option:

    # NOTE(melwitt): CONF.ephemeral_storage_encryption.cipher
    # has format:
    #   <cipher>-<chainmode>-<ivgen>
    #            
    # CONF.ephemeral_storage_encryption.key_size contains the key
    # size       
    #            
    # Equivalent options for qemu-img are separate and map like:
    #   cipher-alg=<cipher>-<keysize>
    #   cipher-mode=<chainmode>
    #   ivgen-alg=<ivgen>
    cipher, chainmode, ivgen = (
        CONF.ephemeral_storage_encryption.cipher.split('-')
    )            
    key_size = CONF.ephemeral_storage_encryption.key_size
    # From the CONF.ephemeral_storage_encryption.key_size help:
    #   "In XTS mode only half of the bits are used for encryption
    #   key."    
    if chainmode == 'xts':
        key_size = int(key_size / 2)
    cipher_alg = f'{cipher}-{key_size}'
    options = {
        'cipher-alg': cipher_alg,
        'cipher-mode': chainmode,
        'ivgen-alg': ivgen,
    }

(wrote this earlier)

After thinking about this more ...

The CONF.ephemeral_storage.cipher option is the format cryptsetup uses which isn't the same as the encryption options being called out here.

Not sure it would be a great idea to try to parse the cryptsetup expected format and translate it to the format qemu-img needs. Seems error prone.

Hello,

I'd suggest to keep only the deprecation topic here and to split default their values changes to a new patch as you already did with 86617.

https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/oslo.messaging/+/866617

Also this patch could be the parent patch of 86617 rather than a separated topic.

Thank you for the review, Hervé! I agree that just removing the setting abruptly is rude, but is leaving the setting in place (as I do) and simply making it do nothing a violation of deprecation practice?

My concern is that simply marking it as deprecated (or changing the default, as in 866617) doesn't actually fix the bug if the user has the setting already present in their config.
The code removed by this patch has been maintained for largely superstitious reasons. I do not know for certain that it's no longer needed :(

ok, then you should at least leave the doc text related to the setting. However you could a some details into this help text by saying something like "this parameter is deprecated and will be ignored if used"...

I'm adding Stephen to this review to get his feedback too.

Yeah, I agree with Herve. You've effectively removed the option here since even if you can still set it, it doesn't actually do anything.

If this is broken enough to cause serious issues then we should deprecate the option and log a warning for users that have set it to a non-default value. We can then remove it in B.

You can ignore the failures. Those were bugs in tox. They've been fixed through [1] and [2]

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message: if the compute service is down hard reboot cannot be used i dont have time to review this curretly full but im not sure this is the correct approach

We don't have the compute service status in real time so it's hard du rely on it

REBOOTING_HARD is also a transient status so it makes sense to handle this status with other transient status.

im not actully back until thursday but just to calrify my concern with this patch was oginginally that it was papering over a deeper error by fixing the sideeffect fo something that should have been prevented before it got in the broken state.

so like dan i think 
https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/nova/+/867832/2/nova/compute/manager.py#1186 is proably fine.

im less sure about https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/nova/+/867832/2/nova/compute/manager.py#1317


the other thing that is in the back of my mind is if the service was down we invoke hard reboot as an rpc Call i belive not a cast? i will have to check that when im back. if so the oslo_messaging should be setting the mandaotry delivery flag on the amqp message which will ensure the rpc is correctly enqueded in teh rpc queue.

that however only ensures that the message is placed in the queue not that it ationed on by the compute service.


im wondering if the api should refuse to make that rpc call if the service is down or if we should be ensuring that no change to the instnace state is done in the api.
i will have to check but the latter seams more feaible.

basicaly i dont think we should allow the api to put the instnace in a trasitive state such as reboot pending. i will have to check the code but i would have assumed the transtation to reboot_pendign shoudl only happen in the compute manager in the compute agent. if that is the case alsready today then the actula case you are protecting against is a restart of the compute agent after the instance has entered the pending state but before it has completed. 


if the instance state is currently being modifed outside of the compute manager we likely shoudl fix that as a seperate followup  patch as that likely will  not be backportable as we are changing where that happens.

anyway ill try to look into the call flow of this later in the week but that is why i was questioning the apporch orginally. it is proably valid and correct to extend the set of transitional states to include the reboot pending states and we should likely proceed with that but im not sure that is the extent of the bug.

> the other thing that is in the back of my mind is if the service was down we invoke hard reboot as an rpc Call i belive not a cast? i will have to check that when im back. if so the oslo_messaging should be setting the mandaotry delivery flag on the amqp message which will ensure the rpc is correctly enqueded in teh rpc queue.

It's a cast, which means we'll queue and return. That also probably means there are more ways to get into this situation, where we cast the message after changing the task state. The cast could be delayed due to network congestion, which could result in other outages, reboots, etc. So more than just threading the needle of firing a reboot seconds before we notice the compute is down.
 
> im wondering if the api should refuse to make that rpc call if the service is down or if we should be ensuring that no change to the instnace state is done in the api.
> i will have to check but the latter seams more feaible.

It can't do this reliably, because there's at least a minute between it being down and us noticing, which I believe is the whole premise of this patch.

> basicaly i dont think we should allow the api to put the instnace in a trasitive state such as reboot pending. 

It doesn't. The compute manager uses the pending state as sort of an ack or progress step. The API puts it into rebooting, and the compute manager moves it to reboot_pending while it actually happens.

> i will have to check the code but i would have assumed the transtation to reboot_pendign shoudl only happen in the compute manager in the compute agent. if that is the case alsready today then the actula case you are protecting against is a restart of the compute agent after the instance has entered the pending state but before it has completed. 

It's both I think.

This is not a priority I think, since it's a very narrow window race mitigation, so I think it can wait until when you're back. That gives Pierre time to reply to my question about the second case too.
I think some residue is left in the tests, but otherwise looks okay to me if that is removed.
Finally removed PENDING states as they were caught in previous if.

nova/compute/manager.py.message:
I think this probably makes sense. The task_state is really a lock on submitting new actions on the instance while another one is potentially queued in rabbit, or just getting started on the compute. We could still have something queued in rabbit when the compute is restarting (the non-pending states above) and the reboot will fail to run when it hits the compute after this, because we'll be clearing the task_state and the expected_task_states check will fail, which is good.

If the task_state is in one of these pending ones, it means it's not queued in rabbit, we started the reboot, and now *we* are restarting, so there's really nothing we can do other than reset it here I think. If the instance is running (per L1180) then it either rebooted or didn't, but resetting to active is the best we can do.

I'm less sure about this, and I'll need to do some more thinking on it I guess. Can you describe the sequence of events that results in this specific bit here? Your comment about failure doesn't seem to match up with what you're doing.
Cool, I think that's the best plan, thanks!

I spotted an other situation where the power state were desynced between the DB and the driver which was handled by this fix. As I do not remember it anymore and I'm unable to find the reproducer test I will remove it from this patch and will create a new one once it come back to me 😕

Okay it took me a bit, but this will return True if we're in either of the pending states, which will cause us to take L1158, and that's why we don't need the pending states added below in the new code.

specs/2023.1/approved/libvirt-pxb-suppor.message: yes this is a well know limitaion

we have discsused doing this in the past but this spec glosses over the work requried to supprot this proeprly.

https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1762119
https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1626130

its been 3 years or more since i looked at this in detail but to day nova does not generate teh pci adresses of any of the devices.

we delegate the virtual pci device adress asignment to libvirt.

if we were to make this change we would need to ensure that vms booted on a non upgraded host could be live migrated to the upgraded host with this feature.

that vm would have to continue to be able to attach/detach interface/volumes without rebooting 

there is also an upgrade question with regards to is it ever ok to take an existing vm and move ti to the new pci toplogy as that may break the guest workload.

going to the pxb approch will change the pci adresses of device in the guest which may break applciation in the guest that use dpdk or otherwise had a depency on the device adress.

on one hand that is ok because nova does not provide a stabel pci adress guarentee but we also do not break it intentionally.

so we need to consider if its ok for a vm to hard reboot and change form the old to new pci toplogy.


i personally do not like the idea of having two was of doing this so i would want this new toplogy  to apploy to all numa vms and ideally all vms but again we need to consider the upgrade impact.

i stongly suspect there might be some impact on live migration in general too in terms of what data we need to pass int eh migrate_data object to generate the correct destination xml.

for example we support transparent live migration swith macvtap sriov vf attachted to guest numa 0

wehn we live migrate form a host with the sriov nic on hsot numa 0 to a host were the pci device is on host numa 1 we would not want to change the virtual guest numa toplogy in this case.


so we would need to enaure that gust  numa 0 is now mapped to host numa 1

for a singel numa node guest that is simple but for a multi numa ndoe guest that is more complex.

yes you are correct about the allowed and denied case however that behavior will need to be enforced in the numa toplogy filter before a host is selected.

im not entirly sure fi we need to include the guest numa node info in the migate_data object or if relaying on the source vm xml is sufficent since the intent is to not change the guest toplogy.

Well, yeah, I think Nova needs to select hosts considering Virtual NUMA Topology by using the numa topology filter.

I see, I can restore the virtual numa topology without migrate_data by referencing the source VM XML.

Thanks for sharing the bugzilla URLs.
I understand that there are requests for enhancements (RFE), but it's not been implemented yet. As you said, to do this, we need to generate a Virtual PCIe Address and index in Nova instead of Libvirt. As for attaching/detaching interfaces/volumes, I think generating virtual PCIe addresses and indexes is closed in a host. So the uniqueness of these values can be achieved relatively easily.

> so we need to consider if its ok for a vm to hard reboot and change form the old to new pci toplogy.

Yes. I think so too.
PCIe devices on existing numa VMs are not linked with any PXB, so I think these devices can be dealt with as non-numa PCIe devices even if the device is linked with a host numa. And PCIe devices on new numa VMs are linked with a PXB. This approach may not need to renumber the virtual PCIe addresses.
 
> for example we support transparent live migration swith macvtap sriov vf attachted to guest numa 0
> 
> wehn we live migrate form a host with the sriov nic on hsot numa 0 to a host were the pci device is on host numa 1 we would not want to change the virtual guest numa toplogy in this case.
> 
> 
> so we would need to enaure that gust  numa 0 is now mapped to host numa 1
> 
> for a singel numa node guest that is simple but for a multi numa ndoe guest that is more complex.

If a guest has multi numa nodes, the PCIe devices on the same virtual guest numa must be linked with the same host numa on both source and destination host like below:

Allowed cases:
- device1 (guest numa0, host numa0) and device2 (guest numa0, host numa0) can be mapped to device1 (guest numa0, host numa 1) and device2(guest numa0, host numa1).

Denied cases:
- device1 (guest numa0, host numa0) and device2 (guest numa0, host numa0) can **NOT** be mapped to device1 (guest numa0, host numa 1) and device2(guest numa0, host numa0). This is because these two devices are linked with the same PXB on the source host, but these devices are linked with different PXBs on the destination host.

In light of this, I feel that Nova need to have a virtual PCIe address and
a virtual guest numa ID for each PCIe device and include it in migrate_data.

there may be datamodle impact if we need to pass addtional information for live migrate.


we may not need to do that but its not entrily cleare if we will have enough info in the exsitng source vm xml and live migrate_data object to ensure the gust numa toplogy is not altereed and the host numa affintiy is correct.

specs/2023.1/approved/libvirt-maxphysadd.message:
From the libvit doc[1]:
>  the maxphysaddr element describes the virtual CPU address size in bits. The hypervisor default is used if the element is missing.
[...]
> The number of bits cannot exceed the number of physical address bits supported by the hypervisor.

So I believe that if we set nothing here then the guest will get the maximum number of bits the hypervisor supports. And even if the tag is set it cannot be bigger to the number of bits the hypervisor supports. So I don't think the proposed change can fix the problem you are describing here.

[1] https://libvirt.org/formatdomain.html#cpu-model-and-topology
Done

I think there are two issues regarding this alternative as follows:

* Ubuntu package maintainers are applying a patch to qemu [1]. It is not included in vanilla qemu and is not available in other distributions.

* This is only the case for hw_maxphysaddr_mode=passthrough and does not include hw_maxphysaddr_mode=emulate. Since hw_maxphysaddr_mode=passthrough requires cpu_mode=host-passthrough to be used [2], this alternative cannot be used in environments that use other cpu_modes.

[1] https://git.launchpad.net/~paelzer/ubuntu/+source/qemu/commit/?id=6ba8b5c843d405e1b067dc8b98ecb8545af78a2b
[2] https://github.com/libvirt/libvirt/blob/v8.7.0/src/qemu/qemu_validate.c#L346-L351

I see. Then my assumption was incorrect about the default behavior. Thanks for correcting me.

I agree that the use case (booting guests with > 1TB ram) is valid and according to you experiment it is not possible today as KVM by default expose only 40bit addressing to the guest.

I found one alternative described in [1] where the author uses a specific machine type that defines more than 40bit address space. I'm not sure how viable this is for you but this seems to be possible today without any nova change.

[1] https://cpaelzer.github.io/blogs/005-guests-bigger-than-1tb/

> The hypervisor default is used if the element is missing.

I experimented with an Intel Xeon (x86-64) and found that the default value is 40bits when using Libvirt/QEMU/KVM. This value is defined as the default for TCG (Tiny Code Generator), and it appears that this value is used as the default even when using KVM [1]. So if we want to set the same value for hypervisor and guest, or any value, we need to explicitly specify maxphysaddr mode.
 
The following is a brief log of the experiment:
 
# my hypervisor has 46bits physical address size.
stack@osdev13:~$ lscpu
Address sizes:                   46 bits physical, 48 bits virtual
 
# In default, the instance has 40bits physical address size.
stack@osdev13:~$ nova boot ...
stack@osdev13:~$ sudo virsh dumpxml 4 | grep maxphysaddr # no output
stack@osdev13:~$ sudo virsh console 4
$ lscpu
Address sizes:       40 bits physical, 48 bits virtual
 
# After adding the setting, the instance has 41bits physical address size.
stack@osdev13:~$ openstack image  set --property hw_maxphysaddr_mode="emulate" --property hw_maxphysaddr_bits="41" cirros-0.5.2-x86_64-disk
stack@osdev13:~$ nova boot ...
 
stack@osdev13:~$ sudo virsh dumpxml 3 | grep maxphysaddr
    <maxphysaddr mode='emulate' bits='41'/>
stack@osdev13:~$ sudo virsh console 3
$ lscpu
Address sizes:       41 bits physical, 48 bits virtual
 
[1] https://github.com/qemu/qemu/blob/2c83112/target/i386/tcg/helper-tcg.h#L28-L32

nova current min libvirt version is 6.0.0 so the address space feature cannot be use by default, it needs to be implemented as an optional feature (and therefore a compute node capability trait) that is only enabled if the host has a new enough libvirt version.

What is the minimum qemu version needed for this? Nova's minimum today is 4.2.0.
Done

Minimum qemu version is 2.7.0 [1]. So, no problem.

[1] https://github.com/libvirt/libvirt/commit/1c1a7cdd4096c59fb0c374529e1e5aea8d43ee9c

In general I'm a bit reluctant to expose such deep hardware details via Nova. I hope other cores can chime in about this.

I see couple of complications though:

1) passthrough mode makes live migration problematic as I imagine different host can have different amount of bits and therefore the amount of bits could change during live migration. I guess changing the number of bits during live migration is not possible from the guest perspective so nova would need to schedule according to the number of bits the host support via passthrough mode.

2) if we allow requesting the number of bits via flavor and image then nova scheduler need to be able to select a host that can provide at least that amount of bits. So we need to model a complex capability logic for this. It won't be just a flag but also a number of bits per host. Placement does not support numeric traits today and these bits are non-consumables so we should not model them as resource class. Therefore the scheduling of this probably needs a new scheduler filter.
Done

I was not thoughtful enough about live migration. Thanks for pointing that out.

> 1) passthrough mode makes live migration problematic as I imagine different host can have different amount of bits and therefore the amount of bits could change during live migration. 

It is not possible to change the number of bits during a live migration. As mentioned above, scheduling that takes into account cpu_mode=host-passthrough has already been realized, so I think that live migration can be done simply by taking advantage of this existing mechanism.


> 2) if we allow requesting the number of bits via flavor and image then nova scheduler need to be able to select a host that can provide at least that amount of bits.

As for numerical comparisons, I feel that the ComputeCapabilitiesFilter can handle this. However, I have no knowledge of filter design, so any advice on creating a new filter or incorporating it into an existing filter would be appreciated. The maximum number of bits allowed by the host can be obtained as libvirt capabilities feature [1], so I think it would be possible to incorporate this into this filter.

[1] https://github.com/libvirt/libvirt/commit/231af0a08ca6c021a8d5daa8a4a9d804b9224ea8

https://docs.openstack.org/nova/latest/admin/cpu-models.html#host-passthrough

> In host-passthrough mode, the guest can only be live-migrated to a target host that matches the source host extremely closely. This includes the physical CPU model and running microcode, and may even include the running kernel. Use this mode only if your compute nodes have a very large degree of homogeneity (i.e. substantially all of your compute nodes use the exact same CPU generation and model), and you make sure to only live-migrate between hosts with exactly matching kernel versions. Failure to do so will result in an inability to support any form of live migration.

Basically we say if you use host-passthrough then nova will not guarantee that the VM can be live migrated. The admin needs to make sure that the live migration is restricted to targets with very similar HW and SW. 
So a similar restriction will be applied to VMs with `hw:maxphysaddr_mode=passthrough`
Done
There will be a compute capability trait to signal if a compute is upgraded and has new enough libvirt and qemu to support this feauture
